FacilityName: TWIN COUNTY SERVICE CO. - PINCKNEYVILLE NH3 SITE

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
                                                          PINCKNEYVILLE, IL    NH3 SITE


1.  FACILITY ACCIDENTIAL RELEASE AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY.

     THE MANAGEMENT AND EMPLOYEES OF TWIN COUNTY SERVICE COMPANY ARE COMMITTED TO THE
     PREVENTION OF ANY ACCIDENTIAL RELEASES OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA.  IF AN ACCIDENTIAL 
     RELEASE SHOULD OCCUR, THE FACILITY IS PREPARED TO WORK WITH THE LOCAL FIRE DEPT.,
     OR OTHER AUTHORITIES, TO MITIGATE ANY RELEASE AND MINIMIZE THE IMPACT OF THE RELEASE
     TO PEOPLE AND THE ENVIRONMENT.

2.  THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED.

     THE PRIMARY ACTIVITY AT THE FACILITY,  WHICH IS LOCATED AT 510 WES KASKASKIA STREET  PINCKNEYVILLE, IL  IS THE STORAGE AND BLENDING OF FERTILIZERS FOR  SALE TO FARMERS.  ANHYDROUS AMMONIA IS RECEIVED, STORED AND DISTRIBUTED FOR DIRECT APPLICATION AS A CROP PRODUCTION NUTRIENT.  THE STORAGE AND HANDLING SYSTEM CONSISTS OF 1 STORAGE TANK (30,000  GALLONS), LOADING RISERS, ASSOCIATED PLUMBING AND NURSE TANKS.  ACCESS TO THE SITE IS RESTRICTED TO AUTHORIZED FACILITY EMPLOYEES, AUTHORIZED MANAGEMENT PERSONNEL AND AUTHORIZED CONTRACTORS.

     THE MAXIMUM QUANTITY OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA THAT CAN BE STORED WOULD BE 
     284,000 POUNDS. THIS INCLUDES ANHYDROUS AMMONIA THAT COULD BE STORED IN NURSE
     TANKS.


3.  THE WORSE-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND THE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO.

     THE WORSE-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO WOULD BE THE RELEASE OF THE TOTAL CONTENTS
     OF A STORAGE TANK AS A GAS OVER 10 MINUTES.  THE MAXIMUN QUANTITY RELEASED WOULD
     BE 140,000 POUNDS, WHICH REPRESENTS THE VOLUME OF THE LARGEST STORAGE TANK AS 
     LIMITED BY DESIGN STARDARDS.

     THE DISTANCE TO THE ENDPOINT OF .14 MG/L FOR THE WORST-CASE SCENARIO IS 1.1 MILES.
 
     THE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO BASED ON THE MOST LIKELY  POTENTIAL INCIDENT IS A
      RELEASE FROM A BREAK IN A TRANSFER HOSE. EMERGENCY

SHUTDOWN PROCEDURES, WHICH INCLUDE THE CLOSING OF TANK VALVES, WAS THE ONLY ACTIVE MITIGATION CONSIDERED TO LIMIT THE AMOUNT OF PRODUCT RELEASED.

     THE DISTANCE TO THE ENDPOINT OF .14 MG/L FOR THE ALTERNATIVE SCENARIO IS .19  MILES.
     THIS RELEASE HAS THE POSSIBILITY OF EXTENDING BEYOUND THE FACILITY BOUNDARY.

4.   THE ACCIDENTIAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM.

      THIS FACILITY COMPLIES WITH EPA'S ACCIDENTIAL RELEASE PREVENTION RULE AND WITH ALL 
      APPLICABLE STATE CODES AND REGULATIONS.  THIS FACILITY HAS IMPLEMENTED THE PROVISION
      OF "SAFETY REQUIREMENTS FOR THE STORAGE AND HANDLING OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA,
      K-61.1",  PUBLISHED BY THE AMERICAN NATIONAL STANDARDS INSTITUTE, INC. AS ADOPTED BY
      STATE REGULATION AND THE STANDARDS OF THE U.S. OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
      ADMINISTRATION (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "STORAGE AND HANDLING OF ANHYDROUS
      AMMONIA".  COMPLIANCE WITH THESE REGULATIONS AND ON-GOING TRAINING OF OUR EMPLOYEES MAKE UP OUR ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM.

5.   FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY.

     THERE HAVE BEEN NO ACCIDENTIAL RELEASES OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA IN THE PAST FIVE 
     YEARS THAT:

        HAVE CAUSED ANY DEATHS, INJURIES, OR SIGNIFICANT PROPERTY DAMAGE AT THE FACILITY;

        TO OUR KNOWLEDGE , HAVE RESULTED IN OFFSITE DEATHS, INJURIES, EVACUATIONS, SHELTER
        IN PLACE, PROPERTY DAMAGE, OR ENVIRONMENTAL DAMAGE. 

6.    THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM.

       THE FACILITY HAS ...  A WRITTEN EMERGENCY ACTION PLAN, IN ACCORDANCE WITH OSHA 
       STANDARD, 29 CFR 1910.38; 
 
        PROVIDED STATE AND LOCAL AUTHORITES THE EMERGENCY PLANNING AND COMMUNITY
        RIGHT- TO- KNOW INFORMATION AS REQUIRED UNDER SARA TITLE III  (EPCRA);

        IN THE EVENT OF AN EMERGENCY INVOLVING ANHYDROUS AMMONIA, IT IS OUR POLICY TO
        NOTIFY THE PINCKNEYVILLE FIRE DEPT. AND THE PERRY COUNTY LEPC.

7.    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY.

      SAFETY IMPROVEMENT IS AN ONGOING PROCESS AT THE FACILITY.  PERI

ODIC EVALUATIONS
      ARE PERFORMED TO ASSESS THE MAINTENANCE OF SAFE CONDITIONS.  THERE ARE NO 
      SPECIFIC SAFETY RECOMMENDATIONS FOR IMPLEMENTATION AT THIS TIME.
